ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned basic information about the history of Nigeria, its government structure, and about the cultural practices of three major ethnic groups in the region (Hausa, Yoruba, Igbo).
I learned about Nigeria and its diaspora

Honestly, this class wasnt really for people familiar with Nigeria. It was taught as if everyone had come from under a rock and had never heard of Nigeria at all. Nigeria is a huge country with even more content to cover, so we skimmed over history, politics, and culture. The Diaspora portion of the class was new and interesting but still a brief overview of all things.
I learned so much about Nigerian art, culture, norms, politics, people, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great overall. Main strength was a great class atmosphere. loved it.
The readings are great the actual class feels under developed.

Strengths: Freedom on essays and presentation to explore what students are interested in, ARTICLE readings
Weaknesses: This course tries to do a lot. It tried to hit every aspect of Nigerian-ness possible without really doing Justice to any of them. Some of this content can be cut out. Even if someone has never heard of Nigeria before, they can learn about something like the food at a restaurant or dance at a party. Instead, we can focus class time on things like Biafra and other nuanced topics in Nigeria because there are a lot of them. The book Culture & Customs of Nigeria reads like an encyclopedia with little nuance or anything to really respond to. This class would benefit more from the articles and niche perspectives.
Strengths: well structured so that students come to class prepared and having done the readings, prof really interesting and fun

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Very good course. You learn a lot, are engaged and its not too stressful

If the student is not Nigerian, the class may be a bit more informative. However, it does not get into much depth and can often just feel like you're listening to a list of fun facts about Nigeria. For example, the Biafra war and its modern implications are not very well discussed, even though it is an important illustration of a major class theme (i.e., understanding the tensions that arise in a post-independence, ethnically-diverse African country).
I would recommend if you need an easier class.
Yes, if youre looking for a free way to explore Nigerian impact across the world.
Yes, it is fascinating and fun, class dynamic is super engaging and intimate, content is super relevant to modern issues everywhere, not just Nigeria
